Decomposeds3 is a storage driver for OpenCloud that uses MinIO, an S3-compatible object storage, for handling file storage efficiently. This setup leverages S3‚Äôs scalability while integrating seamlessly with OpenCloud. Prerequisites: Linux, Mac or Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) Docker Docker Compose
Download the opencloud_full folder (this folder contains a multi-file Docker Compose configuration): git clone https://github.com/opencloud-eu/opencloud.git

Navigate to the Docker Compose configuration folder: cd opencloud/deployments/examples/opencloud_full Enable decomposeds3.yml and minio.yml in the .env file: nano opencloud/deployments/examples/opencloud_full/.env Find all required environment variables env here: decomposeds3-envs Start the deployment with Docker Compose: docker compose up -d This starts all necessary containers in the background.
Edit the /etc/hosts file and add the following entries for local access: 127.0.0.1 cloud.opencloud.test 127.0.0.1 minio.opencloud.test
Login with your browser: https://cloud.opencloud.test user: admin password: admin üéâ Congratulations! You‚Äôve successfully set up and launched OpenCloud! Happy hacking!üöÄ
If you encounter any issues or errors, try finding a solution here: Common Issues & Help
Linux, Mac or Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) Docker
mkdir -p $HOME/opencloud/opencloud-config mkdir -p $HOME/opencloud/opencloud-data
documents.s: 1. Create Required Directories for Bind Mounts

documents.t: docker pull opencloudeu/opencloud-rolling:latest

docker run --rm -it \ -v $HOME/opencloud/opencloud-config:/etc/opencloud \ -v $HOME/opencloud/opencloud-data:/var/lib/opencloud \ -e IDM_ADMIN_PASSWORD=admin \ opencloudeu/opencloud-rolling:latest init You can set your own password using IDM_ADMIN_PASSWORD=your_password. If not set, a password will be auto-generated

docker run \ --name opencloud \ --rm \ -it \ -p 9200:9200 \ -v $HOME/opencloud/opencloud-config:/etc/opencloud \ -v $HOME/opencloud/opencloud-data:/var/lib/opencloud \ -e OC_INSECURE=true \ -e PROXY_HTTP_ADDR=0.0.0.0:9200 \ -e OC_URL=https://localhost:9200 \ opencloudeu/opencloud-rolling:latest
Login with your browser: https://localhost:9200 user: admin password: admin
Your OpenCloud server is now running and ready to use üöÄ
If you encounter any issues or errors, try finding a solution here: Common Issues & Help
Spin up a temporary local instance of OpenCloud using Docker Compose.
Linux, Mac or Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) Git Docker Compose
Download the opencloud_full folder (this folder contains a multi-file Docker Compose configuration): git clone https://github.com/opencloud-eu/opencloud.git

cd into the Docker Compose configuration folder: cd opencloud/deployments/examples/opencloud_full Start the deployment with Docker Compose: docker compose up -d This starts all necessary containers in the background.

Edit the /etc/hosts file and add the following entries for local access: 127.0.0.1 cloud.opencloud.test 127.0.0.1 collabora.opencloud.test 127.0.0.1 wopiserver.opencloud.test 127.0.0.1 onlyoffice.opencloud.test
Login with your browser: https://cloud.opencloud.test user: admin password: admin
Your OpenCloud server is now running and ready to use üöÄ
If you encounter any issues or errors, try finding a solution here: Common Issues & Help
Follow the steps below to install and configure OpenCloud on your system. This example is on Linux Ubuntu 24.04 distribution!

Open a terminal. Update your package list: sudo apt update && upgrade Install Git using the following command: sudo apt install git Clone the OpenCloud repository: git clone https://github.com/opencloud-eu/opencloud.git
documents.s: 1. Install Git and clone the repository

documents.t: Install the golang package: sudo apt install golang -y Install npm (Node Package Manager): sudo apt install npm -y Install corepack globally: sudo npm install -g corepack Enable pnpm using corepack: corepack enable pnpm
documents.s: 2. Update system and install required packages

documents.t: Navigate to the OpenCloud directory: cd opencloud Run the generate process: make clean generate Navigate to the OpenCloud subdirectory: cd opencloud Build OpenCloud: make clean build Initialize OpenCloud with insecure configuration and set an admin password: ./bin/opencloud init --insecure true --admin-password admin Start the OpenCloud server: ./bin/opencloud server
Login with your browser: https://cloud.opencloud.test user: admin password: admin
Your OpenCloud server is now running and ready to use üöÄ
Common Issues & Help
documents.s: If you encounter any issues or errors, try finding a solution here:

documents.t: Category Details Server Operating System Linux MacOS or Windows WSL (for testing and development) Database None ü§† (OpenCloud stores files exclusively on the storage to minimize complexity and ensure maximum reliability) Storage Local storage: Classic file storage on a local file system with POSIX compatibility (e.g., ext4, XFS, ZFS) S3 NFS CephFS (Q3 / 2025) GPFS (Q3 / 2025) Hardware requirements Minimum (Small Deployment - Up to 10 Users) eg. Raspberry Pi 3 1 GHz (Single-core) 512 MB Ram Storage: depends on data usage Medium (Deployment - Up to 1,000 Users) 2 GHz (Dual-core) 8 GB Ram Storage: depends on data usage General: Disk Performance (IOPS): Input/output operations per second (IOPS) should be unrestricted for maintaining optimal performance. The server requirements vary based on load factors such as requests per second, number of client devices per user, file volume, post-processing tasks, and additional apps like Collabora. Proper sizing depends on these variables and should be adjusted accordingly.
Welcome to OpenCloud, your self-hosted file sharing platform: Secure, simple and reliable. This documentation helps you geting started, configure, and maintain OpenCloud.
curl -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dragotin/thisnthat/refs/heads/master/scripts/quickoc.sh | /bin/bash

Getting Started ‚Äì Set up and deploy OpenCloud Configuration ‚Äì Customize and integrate with existing systems and storage coming soon Maintenance ‚Äì Learn how to update, backup and migrate coming soon
Check our FAQs coming soon, Github Discussion, or Matrix Channel. Let‚Äôs get started! üöÄ
docker ps Several containers should be listed here, e.g., for opencloud, traefik, etc.
documents.s: Check whether the containers are running

documents.t: As the local environment is self-signed, you must accept the security risk in your browser. For Firefox: You need to klick on Advanced Confirm the risk with Accept the risk and Contiune

Category Details Types On-Premises Managed Service: Available through partners SaaS: Available through partners Container (recommended) Docker Compose Kubernetes Helm Charts (Q2 / 2025) Bare-Metal OpenCloud can run as a single binary. However, integrating additional services like Collabora, Apache Tika for search, or antivirus is not documented. This deployment is recommended only for experienced users who require minimal file management features. Support is available exclusively from the community.
Category Details Backup strategy Snapshots: Backups can be easily done solely through storage snapshots, eliminating the need for complex database backups.

Category Details Encryption Transport Encryption: TLS Server-Side Encryption: S3 SSE E2EE Client-Side Encryption: Handled exclusively via OS-native encryption Access management RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) 2FA / MFA SSO (LDAP, SAML, OAuth) Auditing & Logging Detailed logs, audit trails, monitoring APIs File Firewall Prevent upload of restricted filetypes based on a allow- or denylist. Antivirus ClamAV (default) ICAP: Integrate 3rd party anti-virus scanner via Internet Content Adaptation Protocol (ICAP) Data Loss Prevention Collabora Secure View

Category Details Integrated Integrated user and group management (LibreIDM) for up to 500 users. Designed for standalone or small-sized deployments that do not rely on third-party identity services, usually for friends and family. External OpenID Connect (OIDC): Integration of external identity providers via Keycloak. Integration of Azure AD, EntraID, ADFS

Regulation Details EU-GDPR Compliant WCAG 2.1 / BITV 2.0 Web Accessibility Compliant. To prevent accessibility regressions, we treat any accessibility violation as a bug and continuously fix these issues as part of our daily software development lifecycle.

Category Details Redundancy & Failover Supported in clustered environments to ensure high availability and system reliability. Automatic failover mechanisms help minimize downtime in case of hardware or software failures.
Category Details Plugins & Extensibility Web: Extension system for adding custom functionality. Server: Microservices architecture for modular and scalable server-side extensions

API Description WebDAV Standard file API for remote file management over HTTP/HTTPS. GraphAPI Microsoft Graph API for managing cloud storage and collaboration spaces. gRPC High-performance RPC framework for microservice communication. OCS API for programmatic file/folder sharing and management. OCM Open Cloud Mesh API for federated file and folder sharing between different file cloud platforms like Cernbox, ownCloud, Nextcloud or Seafile . SSE Server-sent event stream for real-time client notifications. WOPI Microsoft API for integrating Office apps with third-party storage, e.g., Collabora. ICAP Network protocol for offloading content scanning (e.g., antivirus).

Seamless File Synchronization: Access your files across all devices. Secure & Flexible File Sharing: Share files with granular roles, expiration dates, and password protection. Spaces - Collaborative Team Folders: Ensure continuity even if team members leave. Real-Time Collaboration: Work on documents simultaneously with Collabora Web Office. Advanced Search & Organization: Use full-text search, tags, and filters for quick access. Unlimited Storage & Uploads: No file size restrictions. Privacy-First Design: Zero-Knowledge principle ensures admins can't access user content. Cross-Client Availability: Works on Windows, Mac, Linux, Android (soon), iOS (soon), and Web.

Automatic Sync: Keep files up to date across all devices. File Manager Integration: OpenCloud appears as a native drive in your file explorer. Offline Access: Work without an internet connection; sync updates when back online.

Granular Access Roles: Assign users as Viewers, Editors, or Uploaders. One-Click Sharing: Generate share links instantly. Expiration Dates: Set automatic revocation of shared access. Transparency: Keep track of who made changes to files and when. Unlimited Sharing: Share with as many users or groups as needed.

Public Links: Secure external sharing - no login or account needed. Enforced Password Protection: Custom rules for password strength. Link Expiry: Auto-disable links after a set period. Multiple Links per File: Unique links for different recipients; revoke links individually. Anonymous File Drop: Secure uploads without access to other files. Built-in Password Generator: Creates strong passwords automatically.

Project-Based Team Folders: Designed for teams to store, access, and manage files collectively. Files in Spaces belong to multiple users, ensuring continuity even if team members leave. Self-Service Admin Transfer: Easily reassign space owners and assign multiple owners for shared responsibility. Easy Permission Control: Manage user access based on the roles Viewers, Editors, Managers.

Real-Time Editing: Multiple users can work on documents at the same time. No File Transfers: Edit directly in the browser always on the latest version. No Software Installation: Works entirely online, reducing costs and complexity.

Full-Text Search: Find files quickly, even in scanned documents. Live Search: Instant results as you type. Image-to-Text Recognition: Extract text from images and scanned files (OCR - Optical Character Recognition). Advanced Filters: Search by document type, tags, date, or storage location.
Flexible Organization: Categorize files beyond folder structures. Quick Search: Find files faster using keywords. Audit & Compliance: Ensure traceability of important documents.
Easy Recovery: Roll back to previous file versions. Accidental Change Protection: Recover files in case of unintended edits. Deleted File Recovery: Restore files from the trash bin.

Familiar Desktop Features: Right-click context menus. Drag & Drop support between web and desktop. Keyboard Shortcuts: (Ctrl + C, Ctrl + X, Ctrl + V). Multi-Selection: (Ctrl + Click, Shift + Click). Instant UI Updates: No need to refresh when a file is modified.
Block Malicious Uploads: Prevent unwanted file types like .exe or macro files. Allowlist & Denylist Support: Define permitted and blocked file types.

Automated Malware Scanning: Scan all uploaded files before they reach user devices. Early Threat Detection: Prevent infections before they spread. Compliance Assurance: Meets security standards for home and enterprise storage.
Admin Privacy Controls: Admins manage spaces without accessing file content. User-Owned Data: Only designated users can access stored files.
Granular Permission Management: Role-Based Access Control.
GDPR Compliant: Fully meets EU data protection regulations. BITV 2.0 / WCAG 2.1 Compliance: Ensures accessible web usage for all users.
No File Size Limits: Upload large files without restrictions.

Extension System: Add new features and third-party integrations. Custom UI Adjustments: Modify the interface based on specific needs. Simple Installation & Management: Easily install and manage extensions.
On-Premise: Fully self-hosted deployment for maximum control.
Supports Common Formats: Preview images and browser-compatible videos directly in OpenCloud.
Compatible with: Windows, Mac, Linux, Android (soon), iOS (soon), and Web.
In the admin area of OpenCloud you have extensive administration options for your organisation. Here are the most important areas:

Overview of edition and version: You can view information about the Edition and Version of your OpenCloud. Change logo: Click on the 'three-dot menu‚Äô next to the current logo to upload a new logo and customise the appearance.

Overview of users: Here you have an overview of all users of your OpenCloud. Manage users: Depending on your user management settings, you can: Create or delete users Edit users (e.g. change rights or settings) Change quota (storage space) of users Add or remove users in groups Allow or prohibit logins (for individual users)

Overview of the groups: Here you can view the existing groups of your OpenCloud. Manage groups: You can create, edit or delete local groups and add or remove members. Imported groups: External groups that have been imported via an external user management system can not be edited here. These groups are labeled with a lock symbol to indicate that they are locked.

Overview of the Spaces: Here you can see all existing Spaces in your OpenCloud. Space management: As an administrator, you have full rights to: Edit Deactivate or activate Delete These admin settings allow you to comprehensively manage and customise your OpenCloud environment!
NOTE: OpenCloud Desktop is not available yet. We are working on making it available in near future‚Äã To install the OpenCloud Desktop, follow these simple steps:
Open your browser and go to URL comming soon Choose the correct version for your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux) Click Download to start the process
Once the download is complete, double-click the installation file to open it The installation assistant will guide you through the process

Introduction: Click "Continue" to proceed Destination Select: Choose where you want the program to be installed. Click "Continue" Choose Installation Type: Select the version you want to install. Click "Install" Installation Progress: Wait while the software installs Completion: When finished, you‚Äôll see a confirmation message. Click "Close" Now, the Desktop Client is successfully installed and ready to use!
You can synchronize multiple accounts from different OpenCloud servers to your local machine. This allows you to manage files from different instances within the same desktop client.
documents.s: Using Multiple Accounts in OpenCloud Desktop

documents.t: Open OpenCloud Desktop Click on Add Account Follow the standard setup process: Enter the server URL Log in with your credentials Authorize access
documents.s: How to Add a New Account

documents.t: After adding multiple accounts, they will appear in the account overview in the settings menu You can easily switch between them to manage synchronization settings for each account separately

In your File Explorer, each account will have a separate folder By default, the folders are named: OpenCloud (for the first account) OpenCloud (2) (for the second account) OpenCloud (3) (for the third account), and so on This setup ensures that files from different accounts remain organized and do not mix.
‚ö†Ô∏è This page is just a placeholder. If you want to contribute to the dev docs, please visit OpenCloud on Github. Contents will be transferred, during the build process.
If you need to generate logs for troubleshooting, follow these steps:
documents.s: Logging to a Temporary Directory in OpenCloud Desktop

documents.t: Click on Settings ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Log Settings
In the Log Output window, check the box for Enable logging to temporary folder To help the Support-Team and the developers, it is helpful to enable the Log Http traffic
Click Open folder to access the logs. Select the log files for the time frame when the issue occurred. These logs can help diagnose and fix any issues with your OpenCloud Desktop Client.

25-02-17 09:02:35:174 [ info sync.httplogger ]: REQUEST 3710cc12-7391-4793-8e89-00499dc11983 {"request":{"body":{"length":0},"header":{"accept":"*/*","accept-language":"en_DE","original-request-id":"3710cc12-7391-4793-8e89-00499dc11983","user-agent":"Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh) mirall/1.0.0-git (OpenCloud, macos-24.3.0 ClientArchitecture: x86_64 OsArchitecture: arm64)","x-request-id":"3710cc12-7391-4793-8e89-00499dc11983"},"info":{"cached":false,"id":"3710cc12-7391-4793-8e89-00499dc11983","method":"GET","url":"https://cloud.opencloud.test/.well-known/openid-configuration"}}} Log Content Description 25-02-17 09:02:35:174 Timestamp of the request [ info sync.httplogger ] Log category label 3710cc12-7391-4793-8e89-00499dc11983 X-REQUEST-ID (used to match requests & responses) Header: List of HTTP headers Data: [] HTTP bodies (JSON, XML) (112ms) Response time (since the request was sent)

The OpenCloud desktop app sends an X-REQUEST-ID header with every request. This ID helps in finding corresponding requests and responses in logs. You can configure your web server to add the X-REQUEST-ID to its logs for deeper analysis. This feature is useful for debugging sync issues, monitoring network activity, and troubleshooting connectivity problems.
Follow these simple steps to install and configure your OpenCloud Desktop and start syncing your files effortlessly.
Open your OpenCloud Desktop Enter the URL of your OpenCloud instance Click "Continue"
Click "Open web browser" to log in automatically Alternatively, copy the provided URL and paste it into your browser manually
Enter your username and password Click "Login"
Accept the access request to link your account with OpenCloud Desktop.

Choose whether to sync all files or select specific folders (this can be adjusted later). Change the local download directory where your files will be stored. Once you're ready, click Done to complete the setup.
OpenCloud Desktop is now successfully set up. You can start syncing your files seamlessly between your device and the OpenCloud server!
Open the OpenCloud Desktop Go to the Account View Click on the Three-Dot Menu (...) next to the Space you want to configure Choose from the following options:
Opens the selected Space directly in your File Explorer (Windows) or Finder (Mac)
Opens the Space in your web browser If you're not logged in, you may need to sign in first
Manually forces an immediate synchronization of the Space Useful if you want to ensure all changes are uploaded/downloaded right away
Temporarily stops synchronization for the Space Can be resumed anytime by selecting Resume Sync
Stops syncing the Space, but does not delete local files The Space remains on the server, and you can add it again later

Opens a window where you can select specific folders from the Space to sync Helps save storage space by syncing only necessary files Note: Files and folders that are not synced will no longer be available on your local machine.
Adjusting these settings allows you to optimize storage space and network usage, ensuring only the files you need are kept in sync.
You can customize OpenCloud Desktop settings by following these steps:
Click on "Settings" in the top-right corner of OpenCloud Desktop
Enable or disable auto-start when log in Choose whether to show desktop notifications Set your preferred language
Choose to sync hidden files Decide whether deleted files should be moved to the local trash bin Edit the ignored files list Enable a debug log file for troubleshooting
Select how the client handles proxy settings: No proxy Use system proxy (default) Manually enter a proxy
Set bandwidth limits: No limit (default) Automatically adjust limit Set a specific limit manually By adjusting these settings, you can optimize OpenCloud Desktop according to your needs!
If you no longer need OpenCloud Desktop, follow these steps to completely remove it from your system.
Remove your accounts to have a clean system click on the right side of the OpenCloud Desktop on Manage Account then select Remove

The process depends on your operating system: Windows: Uninstall the app through Control Panel > Programs & Features Mac: Move the app to the Trash and empty it Linux: Use your package manager or remove the AppImage file manually
To find out who has edited a file or folder and what actions have been carried out, follow these steps:
documents.s: Viewing the activities of a file or folder

documents.t: Open details‚Äã Right-click on the file or folder, or click on the three dots in the corresponding line. Select Details from the context menu. Select activities‚Äã In the right sidebar opens a window, in this select the ‚ÄúActivities‚Äù item. View activities‚Äã All activities carried out with this file or folder are now displayed. This allows you to track all changes and actions!

Click on the ‚Äú+ New‚Äù button at the top of the bar. In the menu, select either ‚ÄúFolder‚Äù or the desired "file type" that you want to create. Enter a name for the file or folder in the window that appears. Click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù. Done! The file or folder is created. If it is a file, it is automatically opened in edit mode.
documents.s: How to create files and folders

documents.t: Open the context menu by either: right-clicking on the file or folder, or clicking on the three dots on the right in the corresponding line. Select the ‚ÄúRename‚Äù option. Enter the new name for the file or folder in the window that appears. Confirm by clicking on ‚ÄúRename‚Äù. Done! - the new name is applied!

Make a selection: Select the file(s) or folder(s) you want to move. Open the context menu: Right-click on the file or folder, or click on the three dots in the corresponding line. Select the ‚ÄúCut‚Äù option from the menu. (Alternatively, you can use the ‚ÄúCut‚Äù function in the action bar at the top). Select destination: Navigate to the folder or location where the file or folder should be moved to. Click on ‚ÄúPaste here‚Äù in the action bar. The file or folder is now moved to the new location and no longer exists in the original location.
documents.s: How to move files or folders

documents.t: Navigate to ‚ÄúDeleted files‚Äù: Click on ‚ÄúDeleted files‚Äù in the left sidebar. Select Space: Files from your personal space can be found under ‚ÄúPersonal‚Äù. Files from other spaces (e.g. ‚ÄúTestspace‚Äù) can be found in their respective spaces. Select files or folders: Click on the file(s) or folder(s) you want to restore. Open the context menu: Make a right-click, or click on the three dots next to the selection. Select ‚ÄúRestore‚Äù from the menu. (Alternatively, you can also click on ‚ÄúRestore‚Äù in the action bar). Result The files or folders are restored to their original location.
You can use the search bar in the top bar to find files and content quickly.

- Find search bar - The search bar is located at the top of the top bar in the web interface. - Select search area - Click on the drop-down menu next to the search bar. - Select whether you want to search in all files or only in the current folder. - Search function -The searches through file names as well as the content of the files to display relevant results. Use these steps to find your files or folders quickly and efficiently!
documents.s: This is how the search works

documents.t: Now click on the shortcut to open the linked web page or file in a new browser tab. or a "Right-click" and "Open shortcut" on it to open the linked web page or file in a new browser tab.
Click in the input field next to ‚ÄúTags‚Äù. Select an existing tag, or enter a new term to create a new tag. The tag is added and is now linked to the file or folder.
Open the ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù of the file/folder again. Find the tag you want to remove. Click on the ‚Äúx‚Äù next to the tag to delete it. The file or folder is now no longer associated with this tag.

Select the desired files or folders by either: Clicking in the file line or clicking the box at the beginning of the line. Open the context menu By right-clicking or by clicking on the three dots next to the file. or by clicking the download button in the action bar Select ‚ÄúDownload‚Äù from the menu. ZIP files:‚Äã If you download several files or folders, these are saved as a ZIP file. Unzip the ZIP file on your device after downloading.
OpenCloud saves different versions of files. This allows you to restore or download previous versions:
documents.s: Managing versions of files in OpenCloud

documents.t: Open details:‚Äã - Right-click on the file - or click on the three dots in the corresponding file line. - Select ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù from the context menu. Select versions:‚Äã - In the right sidebar that opens select the ‚ÄúVersions‚Äù item. Show versions:‚Äã - All versions of the file are displayed. - You can now restore or download the desired version. These steps give you access to older versions of your files at any time!

Display hidden files Activate or deactivate the display of hidden files. Hidden files are often system or configuration files. Display file extensions Specify whether the file extensions (e.g. .docx, .jpg) should be displayed after the file names. This makes it easier to identify file types. Files per page Specify how many files should be displayed per page in a folder. Useful for navigating in folders with many files. Tile size Customize the size of the icons and buttons: Small tiles for a more compact view. Large tiles for a clearer view. The settings made are applied immediately and offer a personalized user experience.

1. Left Sidebar The sidebar contains the navigation elements such as Spaces, Files, Shares and Settings. 2. App Switcher The menu in the top left corner allows you to switch between different Apps and modules. 3. Top Bar The top bar contains important functions such as the search bar, user actions and global settings. 4. Search Bar Allows you to quickly find files, folders or spaces. 5. Files List Displays all files and folders in a selected view. 6. Breadcrumb Menu Shows the current path of your navigation and allows you to quickly jump back to previous directories. 7. Batch Actions Allows you to edit, move or delete several selected files at the same time. 8. View Modes Provides various display options for the file list: List view Tile view Condensed view 9. View Settings Here you can customize additional display options such as sorting or column selection. 10. User Menu Click on your profile picture in the top right corner to access Settings, Logout and Account Options. 11. Right Sidebar Shows additional information and panels for shares, activities or file details. 12. Actions Here you will find Actions such as Download, Share, Delete or Edit for selected files. 13. Three-Dot Menu Provides further options for files, folders or spaces. 14. Actions Panel Shows possible actions for the selected file, e.g. rename or move. 15. Shares Panel Here you can share files and folders internally or externally and manage permissions. 16. Versions Shows an overview of the versions of a selected file or folder. 17. Activity Panel Shows an overview of changes and activities within a space or file. 18. Context Menu Right-clicking on a file or folder opens the context menu with specific options. With this overview, you can quickly find your way around OpenCloud and use the most important functions efficiently!
Click on your avatar in the top right corner. select "Preferences".
In the settings you will first see your basic account information: Login name First and last name E-mail address Personal storage space Group memberships

Depending on the basic configuration, you can change the following options: Language: Select the desired language for your user interface. Password: Change your password for access to your user account. Theme: Customize the Theme of the user interface according to your preferences. Email notifications: Determine which email notifications you would like to receive from OpenCloud. WebDAV options: Set the WebDAV settings to allow external access to files and folders.
Under Extensions you can configure installed extensions, such as the Progressbar, if available.
Under GDPR you can request a data export of your personal data if you wish. With these settings you can customize and optimize your user account according to your needs!

Default table view‚Äã ‚Üí The classic List view, in which all files and folders are displayed in a detailed table. Condensed table view‚Äã ‚Üí A more compact version of the table view, in which the data is summarized more closely to save space. Tile view‚Äã ‚Üí A view in which files and folders are displayed as tiles. Ideal for visual representations and if you want to access icons quickly. With these options, you can flexibly customize your Fileslist view to choose the best display for you!

Here you will find all the important information to successfully take the first steps in OpenCloud, to be able to solve technical problems flexibly yourself and to be able to answer frequently asked questions.
documents.s: Welcome to the OpenCloud knowledge base

documents.t: User Interface and Navigation:‚Äã Here you will find general information about account settings, customizations and view modes. Manage Files and Folders:‚Äã Here you will find information about the management of files and folders. Share Files and Folders:‚Äã Here you will find information on how to share files and folders. Working in Teams with Spaces:‚Äã Here you will find information for dealing with Spaces. OpenCloud Desktop:‚Äã Here you will find information on how to install and set up the desktop client. NOTE: OpenCloud Desktop is not available yet. We are working on making it available in near future Roles:‚Äã Here you will find information about the different roles that can be assigned. Administration of OpenCloud:‚Äã Here you will find information on what options admins have and how you can use them.

OpenCloud is the file sharing and collaboration solution of the Heinlein Group. Through intelligent file management and a strong open source community, files become valuable resources, effectively structured and usable in the long term. With flexible data rooms and intelligent access rights, teams can access and work together on data anytime, anywhere without barriers, but with a lot of productivity.
Instructions on how to install and set up your own OpenCloud can be found in the "Admin Documentation" under "Quick Start".
Role view download upload edit add delete only view doc, img, pdf with watermark can view (secure) - - - - - - x can view x x - - - - - can upload x x x - - - - can edit x x x x x x -
In a Space, members can have different roles that determine what they can do with shared files and folders.
You can only view documents, pictures, and PDFs. A watermark is added to the files. Downloading is not allowed.
You can view and download files and folders. No restrictions on downloading.
You can view, download, and upload files and folders.
You can edit, add, and delete files and folders. Full access to modify shared content. Each role gives a different level of access, ensuring the right permissions for each user!

Role view download upload edit add delete manage members disable / enable Space delete Space can view x x - - - - - - - can edit x x x x x x - - - can manage x x x x x x x x x In a Space, members can have different roles that give them different levels of access.
This role allows the member to view and download files in the Space, but they cannot make any changes, upload or create new files and folders.

With this role, the member can do everything a "Can View" member can do, plus: Upload files to the Space Create new files and folders Delete files and folders, including their history Restore deleted files

This role gives the member all the abilities of "Can Edit," plus: Add or remove members from the Space Change the roles of other members in the Space Enable and disable the Space Delete the Space Each role determines what a member can do within the Space!
With public links, you can share files and/or folders across organizations.
documents.s: Public links - external sharing of files and folders in OpenCloud

documents.t: Open sharing options:‚Äã Click on the ‚Äúthree dot menu‚Äù next to the file or folder name you want to share. Select Share:‚Äã Select ‚ÄúShare‚Äù from the drop-down menu. Open sidebar window:‚Äã A sidebar window will open on the right side of the screen. Add public link:‚Äã Scroll down in the sidebar window and click on ‚ÄúAdd link‚Äù. Set options for the public link:‚Äã A pop-up window will open where you can configure the following options:
documents.s: Here are the steps to create a public link

documents.t: Rights for the link‚Äã Select the desired access rights for the recipients: ‚ÄúCan view": The link recipient can view and download the file, but cannot edit or upload files. ‚ÄúCan edit": The link recipient can view, download, edit and delete the file, as well as upload files to the folder. ‚ÄúFile Drop (secret)": The link recipient can only upload files, but cannot view or edit the content. Set password for the link:‚Äã Activate the password by entering it in the input field under ‚ÄúPassword‚Äù. The password requirements appear below the input field. Here are three icons: One icon displays the password unencrypted to verify your entry. The next icon copies the password to the clipboard. The last icon generates a random password automatically. Set expiration date for the link:‚Äã Enter a date under ‚ÄúExpiry date‚Äù to set a time limit for the link. Once the date has expired, the link is no longer accessible. If you do not enter a date, the link will not expire.

Once all options have been set, click on ‚ÄúCopy link‚Äù to generate the public link. The link is now created and can be shared with the recipients. Now you know how you can share files and folders securely and individually with external users.

The ‚ÄúFile Drop‚Äù allows people who receive a specific link (the so-called ‚Äúlink recipients‚Äù) to upload files to a shared folder. The trick: The ‚Äúlink recipients‚Äù cannot see the files already in the folder.
documents.s: File Drop (secret) - This is how it works

documents.t: Click on the ‚Äúthree dot menu‚Äù next to the file or folder name you want to share. Select ‚ÄúShare‚Äù from the drop-down menu. A sidebar window will open on the right-hand side of the screen. At the sidebar window, you will find the area for ‚ÄúPublic links‚Äù. There click on the "Add link" button. Select the option for "Secret File Drop". Type a password and confirm the entries with click on "copy link". You can also set an "Expiry date", if you want the link to expire. Click here, if you want to know how to set the Expiry date. Now you send the link and the password to a "link recipient".

The ‚Äúlink recipient‚Äù opens the received link in a browser. The ‚Äúlink recipient‚Äù enters the password and then clicks on ‚ÄúContinue‚Äù. Upload files: The ‚ÄúFile drop folder‚Äù is opened. The ‚Äúlink recipient‚Äù can upload their files here without being able to view the existing contents of the folder. As confirmation that the upload was successful, a pop-up window appears in the lower right corner. Important‚Äã The ‚Äúlink recipient‚Äù does not have access to existing files - they can only add new files. Now you know how you can share a file drop link
Role Personal Space create Spaces can be Space Manager manage Users and Groups Administrator x x x x Space Admin x x x - User x - x - User Light - - x -

The Administrator role in OpenCloud has the same abilities like a Space Admin but in addition it has special permissions to manage users, groups, and system settings. However, administrators do not have direct access to Space data or the ability to add users to Spaces where they don't have the "can manage" role. Below are the key actions an administrator can perform: Create and Delete local Users & Groups‚Äã Administrators can add new local users and remove existing local users from the system. They can also create and delete local groups to organize users efficiently. Edit Users & Groups‚Äã User details such as names, emails, and roles can be modified. Groups can be updated by adding or removing members as needed. Prevent Login‚Äã If necessary, administrators can disable user accounts, preventing them from logging in. This is useful for security reasons or when an account is no longer needed. Manage Spaces (without Access to Space Data)‚Äã Administrators can manage Spaces like enable, disable or delte them and rename it or adjust the quota, even if they don't have the "can manage" role. However, they cannot access the files inside a Space or add members to it. Change the Logo‚Äã The system logo can be updated to reflect the company branding. This can be done in the Admin Settings under the "General" section.

A Space Admin has the highest level of control over Spaces. They can: Create and manage Spaces Be assigned the "Can Edit" role in Spaces they didn‚Äôt create Have a personal Space where they can create files, folders, and upload data

A regular User has access to their own Space and can be part of other Spaces. They can: Create files and folders in their personal Space Upload and manage their own data Be added as a member to a Space Can have the "Can Edit" role in a Space
A User Light has limited access and does not have their own personal Space. They can: Be added as a member to a Space Can have the "Can Edit" role in a Space They do not have a personal Space

Open sharing options‚Äã Click on the ‚Äúthree dot menu‚Äù next to the file or folder name you want to share. Select share‚Äã Select ‚ÄúShare‚Äù from the drop-down menu. Sidebar window appears‚Äã A sidebar window will open on the right-hand side of the screen. Set up internal sharing‚Äã At the top of the sidebar window, you will find the area for ‚ÄúInternal sharing‚Äù. Search for individual members or entire groups by entering them in the search bar. Select the people or groups with whom you would like to share the folder or file. Set access rights‚Äã Select the rights for the selected members or groups: ‚ÄúCan view": Members can only view and download the file, but cannot edit it or upload it to shared folders. ‚ÄúCan upload": Members can view and download the file and upload their own files to the shared folder. ‚ÄúCan edit": Members have the same rights as in "can upload", but can also create new files, edit existing files and delete them.
documents.s: Here are the steps to share files or folders with other members or groups internally

documents.t: Click on ‚ÄúShare‚Äù to confirm the selection. The shared members or groups are listed under ‚Äúshared with‚Äù in the same window. Now you know how you share files and folders within your organization and manage access accordingly
With Spaces you can share data with specific people within your organization. All members of a Space have the defined access to the data, and you can customize the editing rights for each member.
documents.s: Create Spaces and share data in OpenCloud

documents.t: Spaces can only be permanently shared within your own organization.
Open menu Go to the menu item "Spaces‚Äù in the left sidebar Create new Space Click on "+ New Space‚Äù Name a Space Enter the desired name for the Space. create Space Click on "Create‚Äù.
Your new Space now appears under "Spaces‚Äù and is ready to be used. Now you know how to quickly and easily create a Space and can start sharing data!
You can customize your Space in two places: In the Space overview In the Space itself
Open ‚ÄúContext Menu‚Äù‚Äã Click on the ‚ÄúContext menu‚Äù in the Space overview or directly in the Space.

Here you can change the following options‚Äã Edit description Write your description in the opened texteditor, save and close it. Edit subtitle In the pop-up window, write your subtitle and confirm Edit image Select the image you want for your Space from the pop-up window and confirm Set an icon Select the icon you want for your Space from the pop-up window Change description directly‚Äã The description of the Space can also be changed directly in the Space by clicking on the pen next to the description. Now you know how you can design and customize the Space to your liking!

Open Space Go to your Space and open the members menu. Search for a member: In the members menu, you can search for the user from your organization that you want to add. Assign rights: Select the desired rights for the member, e.g. whether the person may only read or also edit. Add: Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù to invite the member to the Space. Change rights: To change the rights of a member, open the members menu, click on the corresponding user and select the desired new rights. Remove members: Open the members menu, click on the three-dot menu next to the member you want to remove and select ‚ÄúRemove member‚Äù. The removed member immediately loses access to the space.

The added member has immediate access to the Space. Attention: Every user with the ‚Äúcan manage‚Äù right has the authorization to deactivate and delete the Space. A deleted Space cannot be restored, so be careful who you grant these rights to. Now you know how to add members to your Space and set the permissions accordingly!
A Space can be disabled and later enabled in various ways. This function can only be performed by a Space Admin or the Administrator.
documents.s: Disable and Enable a Space in OpenCloud

documents.t: via the Space overview Select the desired Space. Click on Disable in the top taskbar. Alternatively, you can click on the three dots menu in the Space overview and select Disable from the menu. In the Space Go directly to the Space. There, click on the three dots menu and select Disable. Confirm deactivation Confirm the deactivation. Note: No data will be deleted, but only the Space Admin or the Administrator can enable the Space.

Disabled Space After the Space has been disabled, the Enable option now appears in place of Disable. Click on it to enable the Space. Space not visible If the Space is not visible, the filter Show disabled Spaces may be enabled. Click on the filter and the Space will appear so that it can be enabled.

Administrator access In the Administration settings under Spaces, the Administrator can also enable the Space. Enable Space The Administrator clicks on the three dots menu and selects Enable. Confirm the selection by clicking on Enable. Space appears again The Space is now displayed again in the Space Overview. Now you know how you can disable a Space and enable it again if required.
Before you can delete a Space, it must first be disabled. Here are the steps you should follow:

Disable Space Follow the instructions for Disable a Space to set the Space to the deactivated state before deleting it. Make Space visible If the Space is no longer visible after deactivation, click on the Include disabled filter to display it again.

Select Space Select the Space you want to delete. Execute deletion Click on Delete in the top bar, or Open the three-dot menu and select Delete Confirm that you are sure that you want to delete the space

‚ö†Ô∏è Attention! A deleted Space cannot be restored. It is permanently and irretrievably deleted. Therefore, be careful to whom you grant can manage rights for your Space. Please remember to ensure that no important data is lost before deleting. Now you know how to delete a space.

Open context menu Click on the three dots menu or do a right click on the Space in the Space Overview and select Rename Enter new name Enter the new name for the Space and confirm. Now your Space is renamed
As a Space administrator, you can adjust the storage capacity (quota) of a Space to increase or decrease the available storage space as required. This is how it works:
documents.s: Edit the quota of a Space

documents.t: Edit quota Select the Edit quota option in the Top-Bar or in the Context-Menu Set new quota Two options are available in the window that opens: Select a default size (e.g. 5 GB) from the drop-down menu. Enter an individual storage size. Confirm changes Click on Confirm to apply the change. The quota of the space is updated according to the new settings.
documents.s: Steps to edit the Space quota
